titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jean Piper papers on Hunts Lane, Brooklyn Heights 1977.577
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-17T10:28-0500

did.unittitle: Jean Piper papers on Hunts Lane, Brooklyn Heights

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Hunts Lane in Brooklyn, a small lane off Henry Street in the neighborhood of Brooklyn Heights, was most likely named after John Hunt, who purchased land from the Pierrepont family in 1842.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Jean Piper papers on Hunts Lane, Brooklyn Heights, 1977.577, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of papers of Jean Piper relating to the proper naming of Hunts Lane (formerly Hunts Alley). Included is correspondence between Piper and the Brooklyn Post Office and Board of Alderman, a resolution changing the name of Hunts Alley to Hunts Lane, and an essay by Piper giving a brief history of the Hunt family farm, as well as her desire to have the street recognized as a lane instead of an alley. Materials date from 1929.
